required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 13, 2016
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Prospective, Randomized, Blinded,Comparative Efficacy and Safety Trial of Vapocoolant (Pain Ease Medium Stream) for Venipuncture

brief_summary.textblock: To determine the efficacy and safety of vapocoolant spray (Pain Ease Medium Stream) in decreasing the pain of venipuncture ("blood draw")

detailed_description.textblock: This is a prospective, randomized, blinded, comparator study. This study design is considered standard for establishing safety and efficacy data. Active treatment vapocoolant spray (Pain Ease Medium Stream) spray) will be used. There will be a placebo (sterile water) in this study. The population selected for this study, adults (excluding the very old, > 80 years old) represents a patient population that may benefit from vapocoolant spray. This is a patient population that according to the treating health care provider already requires venipuncture for "blood draw" but not intravenous cannulation. Because venipuncture is a painful procedure, vapocoolant may confer benefit for the relief of pain.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Caregiver, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Pain Scale on Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) ( 0 to 10)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Less than 10 minutes after stream application.
primary_outcome.description: NRS scale: 0-10 ; No pain (0) - (5) moderate pain - Worst pain (10)

arm_group.description: Application of Vapocoolant (Pain Ease Medium Stream) for 4-10 seconds onto venipuncture site.
Application of sterile water stream ( nature's tears) for 4-10 seconds onto the venipuncture site.

intervention.description: Topical stream 4-10 seconds duration to skin.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient needing venipuncture ("blood draw') but not intravenous cannulation
- Adult 18 years and older up to and and including 80 years old
- Stable patient
- Mentally competent patient able to understand the consent form
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with any allergies to the spray components (e.g. 1,1,1,3,3 pentafluoropropane or 1,1,1,2, tetrafluoroethane )
- Critically ill or unstable (e.g. sepsis or shock)
- Extremes of age: geriatric (> 80 years) or pediatric ( < 18 years old)
- Pregnant
- Venipuncture site located in area of compromised blood supply. Examples include : patients with peripheral vascular disease, gangrene, Raynaud's disease, Buerger's disease.
- Venipuncture site located in area of insensitive skin; patients with a peripheral neuropathy including diabetic neuropathy.
- Patient intolerant of cold or with hypersensitivity to the cold.
- Patient unable or unwilling to give consent.
- Prior experience with vapocoolant spray
- Currently in another research trial

reference.citation: Farion KJ, Splinter KL, Newhook K, Gaboury I, Splinter WM. The effect of vapocoolant spray on pain due to intravenous cannulation in children: a randomized controlled trial. CMAJ. 2008 Jul 1;179(1):31-6. doi: 10.1503/cmaj.070874.

Hijazi R, Taylor D, Richardson J. Effect of topical alkane vapocoolant spray on pain with intravenous cannulation in patients in emergency departments: randomised double blind placebo controlled trial. BMJ. 2009 Feb 10;338:b215. doi: 10.1136/bmj.b215.

group.title: Placebo (Normal Saline, Nature&Apos;s Tears)
group.description: Application of sterile water stream (manufacturer above) for 4-10 seconds onto the venipuncture site. Sterile water (Nature's Tears): Topical stream of sterile water ( Nature's Tears ) 4-10 seconds duration to skin.

group.title: Vapocoolant (Pain Ease Medium Stream )
group.description: Application of Vapocoolant (Pain Ease Medium Stream) for 4-10 seconds onto venipuncture site. Vapocoolant (Pain Ease): Topical stream 4-10 seconds duration to skin.

participants_list.participants: trial to enroll 50 in each group for total of 100

baseline.population: pain after spray with placebo or vapocoolant

group.title: Vapocoolant (Pain Ease Medium Stream )
group.description: Application of Vapocoolant (Pain Ease Medium Stream) for 4-10 seconds onto venipuncture site. Vapocoolant (Pain Ease): Topical stream 4-10 seconds duration to skin.

group.title: Nature's Tears
group.description: Application of sterile water stream (manufacturer above) for 4-10 seconds onto the venipuncture site. Sterile water (Nature's Tears): Topical stream of sterile water ( Nature's Tears ) 4-10 seconds duration to skin.

measure.title: Numeric rating scale (NRS)
measure.description: Baseline numeric rating scale is the pain assessment immediately after the sprays were administered and was before venipuncture was done.

outcome.title: Pain Scale on Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) ( 0 to 10)
outcome.description: NRS scale: 0-10 ; No pain (0) - (5) moderate pain - Worst pain (10)
outcome.time_frame: Less than 10 minutes after stream application.
outcome.population: equal numbers in both groups by randomization to 50 in each group to look at NRS by change of 2 in NRS scale between the 2 groups

reported_events.desc: Time frame = the time the patients were in the emergency department Skin assessments were done within 10 minutes after spray application

group.title: Vapocoolant (Pain Ease Medium Stream )
group.description: Application of Vapocoolant (Pain Ease Medium Stream) for 4-10 seconds onto venipuncture site. Vapocoolant (Pain Ease): Topical stream 4-10 seconds duration to skin.

event.description: "skin felt cool" at 10 minutes no skin abnormalities seen

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: This study enrolled only adults. No pediatric patients were enrolled. However, an earlier study by Farion KJ et al in CMAJ in 2008 found that the use of a vapocoolant (pain-ease) significantly decreased the pain of intravenous cannulation in children

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Dr. Sharon E. Mace, Director of Research, ESI
